sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for the verb to be able to.

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

cit.quote: yigdar il-ʔinsān yāxuḏ min-ha kull kilmä bi-kilmit-a
Men can take every word literally
I cannot eat at someone else's house
We could not stretch our legs in prison
He could not do anything with her

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Value given only for al-Qāṣīm
Deduced from example

cit.quote: w inʕābbiy fih ǧawālīn ṃayyah. ilkān, wala maxza, nigdaṛ inšīlhin inšīlhin
and we pour gallons of water into it. If, no offence intended, we are able to carry them (f.), we carry them

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Deduced from example

cit.quote: law inn-ak ṛaǧil kān taǧawwazt, iw ʕārif innī́ gādir ʕa lǧīzih iw bišūf-nī́ miš mitǧawwiz
if you were a (real) man you would have gotten married, and he knew that I was (financially) able to get married, but he sees that I am not
they can´t then travel to them

wib:featureValueObservation.note: "Min with a pronoun suffix signifying 'can, (physically) able to' in negative or interrogative clauses" (Shawarbah 2012:278)

cit.quote: and we'll be able to have our way with them, which we wouldn't with ʕlliy
She cannot speak with him at start.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Deducted from example.
Deducted from example
only created for the gahawa
only created for the gahawa
yāf may be followed by kīf

cit.quote: The exaxt translation provided in the source is "he managed to do something"

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The source attributes this reflex to Bahrain in general and not specifically to the Baḥārna
The source attributes this reflex to Bahrain in general and not specifically to the Baḥārna
The source attributes this reflex to Bahrain in general and not specifically to the Baḥārna
The source attributes this reflex to Bahrain in general and not specifically to the Baḥārna
The source attributes this reflex to Bahrain in general and not specifically to the Baḥārna
This value is used only to express the negative and in an impersonal manner
The proper translation provided is "to allow" but in certain expressions it conveys the meaning of "to be able to"
The proper translation provided is "to be in time for, to have the time to, to give the time to" but in certain expressions it conveys the meaning of "to be able to"
This form was attested in the questionnaire, but could not be found anywhere else.
This form was attested in the questionnaire, but could not be found anywhere else.

cit.quote: If you can meet him, do it!

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Cf. Mehri hǝm = be able.
This form was found on the internet.
Has a slight touch of MSA
To be capable/to be up to do something.
